stem: A young man presents with a thunderclap headache. A CT examination is performed. Sub-arachnoid blood is seen with a localised clot which has a maximum thickness of 2 mm. No intraventricular nor parenchymal blood is seen. What is the Fisher Grade?

A middle-aged man with progressive lower-extremity weakness undergoes an MRI examination of the spine. T2W images demonstrate multiple small vessel flow voids on the cord pial surface, but no flow voids within the cord. The cord is enlarged, with oedema sparing the periphery. Which type of spinal cord arteriovenous malformation does this represent?

A neonate presents with unilateral leukocoria and microphthalmia. An US reveals a hyperechoic band within the globe. CT demonstrates a hyperdense vitreous, fluid-fluid levels and an absence of calcification. No focal mass is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30 year old man presents with a progressive neurological deficit. A CT head demonstrates strongly enhancing, serpiginous structures. Catheter angiography subsequently visualises the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a standard radiographic projection of the skull?
A patient presents with an enlarged, palpable cervical lymph node. Thyroid carcinoma is suspected, and an US is performed. What imaging feature would make a malignant node more likely?
options: Short axis to long axis ratio (S/L) of 0.25
Central hilar flow pattern on colour Doppler imaging
Absence of visible subcapsular flow on colour Doppler imaging

stem: A 30 year old man with learning difficulties presents to A&E after suffering facial injuries. An orthopantomogram is performed and demonstrates a multi-locular radiolucent lesion in the angle of the mandible. He suffered from multiple carcinomatous lesions of the skin in childhood. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A neck lump is found on clinical examination. Axial MR images of the neck demonstrate a mass displacing the parapharyngeal space posteromedially and the styloid musculature posteriorly. In which fascial space is the mass most likely to be located?
A plain radiograph is performed on a male child. Unilateral, premature fusion of both the coronal and lambdoid sutures is evident. What is the most appropriate description?

A skull radiograph is performed on a patient who presented with a possible head injury. There is a solitary skull vault lucency, with a surrounding area of sclerosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient presents with sensorineural hearing loss. A cerebellopontine angle mass is demonstrated on MR imaging. Which of the following features support a diagnosis of schwannoma over meningioma?
options: High signal intensity relative to grey matter on T2W imaging

stem: A patient develops dissociated anaesthesia of the legs. An MRI brain demonstrates herniation of the cerebellar tonsils. Which of the following is not associated with Chiari type I malformation?
options: Incomplete ossification of the C1 ring

stem: A middle-aged man presents with an acute onset facial nerve palsy and has MR imaging with the i.v. administration of gadolinium. Which of the following features would support the diagnosis of Bell’s palsy?
options: Enhancement of the tympanic portion of the facial nerve
Enhancement of the intracanalicular portion of the facial nerve
Enhancement of the mastoid portion of the facial nerve

stem: Which of the following structures does not typically calcify in normal individuals?
A patient presents with multiple relapsing focal neurological deficits. Which MR imaging feature would be unusual in multiple sclerosis?

A patient with a known intracerebral neoplasm suddenly deteriorates. A CT head demonstrates enlargement of the left CPA cistern and new areas of high attenuation in the anterior midbrain. Which type of cerebral herniation is most likely?

A patient presents with a lump thought to be arising from the thyroid gland. An US is arranged for further evaluation which confirms the solid lesion is thyroid in origin. Which imaging feature would be most suggestive of a malignant lesion?

A young patient presents with dissociated sensory loss. MRI demonstrates spinal cord enlargement with an intra-medullary lesion. Which of the following features would favour the diagnosis of astrocytoma, rather than ependymoma?
A patient is seen in the neurology clinic, referred by his GP with a chronic headache. Which of the following features would not be an indication for imaging?
options: Recurrent episodes of headache in the early morning

stem: A patient presents with gradual onset of sensory symptoms affecting the right hand. CT reveals a superficial mass within the fronto-parietal region. Which imaging feature would not support the diagnosis of meningioma?
options: Inward bulging of the grey-white junction

stem: A 45-year-old female presents with facial pain and abnormal eye movements. A cerebellopontine angle lesion is identified on MR imaging. Which feature would not be consistent with an epidermoid tumour?
options: Iso-intense to CSF on T1W Imaging
Low signal on balanced sequence/true FISP

stem: A young man suffers a subarachnoid haemorrhage. A CT angiogram fails to demonstrate an aneurysm, and a cerebral angiogram is performed. Which of the following is not a recognised complication of cerebral angiography?
A man referred from the memory clinic has a 99Tc-HMPAO cerebral SPECT. Temporo-parietal hypoperfusion is found. What is the most likely diagnosis?
An MRI reveals a lesion within the globus pallidus. Which of the following is incorrect?
options: The lesion is within the lenticular nucleus
The lesion is within the corpus striatum
The lesion is within the lentiform nucleus
The lesion is within the diencephalon
The lesion is within the striatum

stem: A 30-year-old pregnant patient is found unconscious and neurological examination reveals bilateral Babinski’s sign. CT and MR imaging are suggestive of cerebral infarction. Which of the following imaging features would support an arterial rather than a venous infarct?
options: A hyperdense superior sagittal sinus on unenhanced CT imaging
Bilateral areas of increased T2W signal

stem: A female patient is seen in the endocrine clinic and a pituitary microadenoma is suspected. Regarding the imaging of the pituitary gland, which of the following is an abnormal appearance?
options: High signal in the posterior pituitary on T1W
Intermediate signal intensity in the posterior pituitary on T2W
Enhancement of the posterior pituitary on T1W after gadolinium administration
Convex superior margin of the pituitary gland in pregnant subjects
High signal in the anterior pituitary on T2W

stem: A patient with known HIV develops neurological symptoms and a CT head examination is performed. Multiple ring-enhancing lesions are seen. What imaging features would support the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis rather than lymphoma?
Thickening of the extra-ocular muscles is seen on MR imaging. What features would support the diagnosis of pseudotumour rather than thyroid ophthalmopathy?
An MRI brain is performed and a lesion is seen in the suprasellar region. Which of the following imaging characteristics is not typical?
options: Epidermoid — isointense to CSF on T1W and T2W
Tuber cinerum — isointense to grey matter on T1W
Schwannoma — T1W hypointensity and marked enhancement with iv. gadolinium
Rathke’s cleft cyst — T1W hypointensity and lack of enhancement with iv. gadolinium

stem: A teenager presents with a small midline neck lump. On examination, the lump is noted to move superiorly upon protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding such lesions?
options: Presentation with a painless midline mass is common
Can appear anechoic by US imaging
Can appear uniformly echogenic by US imaging
Can appear heterogeneous by US imaging

stem: An adolescent undergoes MR imaging and an incidental suprasellar mass is found. What feature would suggest a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma rather than a Rathke cleft cyst?
options: Predominantly high signal on T1W imaging

stem: An elderly gentleman has an episode of amaurosis fugax and undergoes Doppler ultrasound assessment of his carotid arteries. Which of the following features is not an indication of either internal carotid artery or common carotid artery stenosis?
options: ICA/CCA peak systolic velocity ratio of 1.5

stem: An elderly gentleman presents with a hemiplegia. Both MR diffusion and perfusion-weighted imaging are performed. Which of the following would suggest the presence of an ischaemic penumbra?
options: A lesion which appears the same size on diffusion and perfusion weighted imaging
A lesion which appears larger on perfusion-weighted than diffusion-weighted imaging
Visualisation of a lesion on perfusion-weighted imaging
Changes in the perfusion parameters over time
A lesion which appears larger on diffusion-weighted than perfusion-weighted imaging

stem: A 55-year-old patient presents with head trauma. A CT head is performed and bilateral calcification of his basal ganglia is noted. Which of the following is not a recognised cause?

An elderly, hypertensive man is found collapsed. MR imaging demonstrates a large intracerebral haematoma, with intermediate signal intensity on T1W and high signal intensity on T2W. How old is the haematoma likely to be?

An elderly lady has an MRI brain examination as part of a research study. A number of lesions are noted in the basal ganglia, most prominently around the atria. They are hypointense to brain parenchyma on T1W, hyperintense to brain parenchyma on T2W and isointense to CSF on FLAIR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A lateral skull x-ray in a short male child demonstrates multiple wormian bones and a small, receding jaw, with an obtuse angle to the mandible. What syndrome could explain these findings?

An elderly, hypertensive man was found collapsed. MR imaging reveals a large infarct, with low signal intensity on T1W, high signal intensity on T2W, low signal on the ADC map, and high signal on DWI. How old is the infarct likely to be?
A young man suffers a severe head injury and a CT head identifies a significant haematoma. Which feature would be more suggestive of an extra-dural, rather than sub-dural haematoma?
MR imaging demonstrates bilateral acoustic schwannomas. Which of the following is not a recognised feature of neurofibromatosis type 2?

A neonate presents with a soft, painless mass in the posterior triangle of the neck. MR imaging demonstrates a multi-loculated, insinuating mass of intermediate signal on T1W and high signal on T2W. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which two optic nerves are most commonly affected by skull base injury?
Which of the following imaging features would not support the diagnosis of diffuse axonal injury?
options: Multiple ovoid lesions ranging in size from 5—15 mm
Lesions seen more prominently on CT than MR imaging
On CT imaging, lesions demonstrate a low attenuation margin

stem: A male adolescent suffers from recurrent epistaxis and the subsequent imaging investigations reveal a likely juvenile angiofibroma. Regarding this condition, which of the following statements is incorrect?
options: The majority extend within the sphenoid sinus
The majority extend within the pterygopalatine fossa
Embolisation may be undertaken via the maxillary artery
Biopsy should be performed prior to therapy to confirm the diagnosis
The lesion may recur following treatment

stem: A smoker suffers from a hoarse voice and is found to have a glottic laryngeal carcinoma. The tumour is seen to have supra-glottic extension and fixes the cords. What is the tumour stage?

A 61-year-old, known hypertensive man has an episode of expressive dysphasia which lasts a total of 90 minutes and resolves spontaneously in the A&E department. He is currently asymptomatic with no focal neurology. What is the most appropriate management step?
options: Carotid imaging within 48 hours, with a view to endarterectomy within 1 week
Urgent CT (with CT angiogram/ perfusion if available)

stem: A 40-year-old man presents with a seizure and a CT head reveals an intracranial lesion. An oligodendroglioma is suspected. Which feature would be least expected with this diagnosis?
Which of the following is not involved in a Le Fort type I fracture?
options: Anterior wall of the maxillary sinus
Posterior-lateral wall of the maxillary sinus
Medial wall of the maxillary sinus
Central Nervous System and Head & Neck Mock Paper Questions

stem: A young man is involved in an RTA and arrives in hospital with a markedly reduced GCS. CT imaging reveals a fracture of the temporal bone. Which of the following features would be more typical of a transverse, rather than longitudinal fracture of the temporal bone?
options: Bleeding from the external auditory canal

stem: A neonate is noted to have cataracts, microcephaly, basal ganglia calcification and a patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following in utero infections could explain these features?

MR imaging of a neonatal brain reveals an absent septum pellucidum, corpus callosum, third ventricle, and interhemispheric fissure. The thalami are fused. Which variant of holoprosencephaly does this most likely represent?

After review of a CT head examination, IV contrast medium is administered. The enhancement follows the gyral/sulcal pattern and involves the meninges around the basal cisterns. Which of the following conditions can give rise to this enhancement pattern?

A patient has a glioma resected and the post-surgical tumour bed is examined by CT imaging. Images are acquired both before and after the administration of IV contrast medium. Which of the following features would lead one to suspect that there is residual tumour?
options: Linear enhancement around the pre-operative tumour bed
Enhancement within the pre-operative tumour bed, 1 day after surgery
Enhancement within the pre-operative tumour bed, 4 days after surgery

stem: An adolescent undergoes MR imaging after having a number of seizures. A mass is demonstrated within the periphery of the right temporal lobe. The lesion contains a number of cysts. There is no surrounding oedema and the mass does not enhance after the administration of IV gadolinium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A patient presents with a focal neurological deficit. CT imaging reveals multiple haemorrhagic foci. Which of the following features would be more consistent with haemorrhagic metastases, rather than haemorrhagic cerebrovascular malformations?
options: Surrounding oedema within the first week from symptom onset
Lack of enhancement with IV contrast medium

stem: A patient presents with left-sided proptosis. A CT reveals a low-density mass causing expansion of the frontal sinus. There is focal thinning of the bony walls, dehiscence of the orbital roof, and mass effect on the globe. There is no enhancement with IV contrast medium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient with chronic alcoholic liver disease is admitted with confusion. MR imaging of the brain is performed. Which of the following imaging features is not associated with alcohol intake?
options: Hyperintense foci within the corpus callosum on T2W
Hyperintense lesions within the pons on T2W

stem: A child with fever and otalgia has a CT examination performed. There is opacification of both the middle ear and mastoid. Fluid levels can be seen. There is bony resorption of the mastoid and haziness of the air cell walls. What is the most appropriate description?
A patient presents with pulsatile tinnitus. CT reveals a mass in the left temporal bone and there is focal uptake with 141y octreotide imaging. Which of the following is least likely?
options: Metastasis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid

stem: A 5-year-old child presents with headache, vomiting, and ataxia. On CT imaging, a high attenuation posterior fossa mass is seen to arise from the midline of the roof of the 4th ventricle. Given the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is incorrect?
options: There is hydrocephalus in the majority
The mass tends to be hyperintense on TIWw
There is an association between enhancing pial nodules and seizures
In children older than 3 years, the mass tends to be resected

stem: You are reporting an MR of the nasal sinuses, and you notice a mass within the right maxillary sinus. The request card reads: ‘?squamous cell carcinoma ?mucocoele/secretions.’ Which of the following features would be more supportive of a diagnosis of benign disease, rather than squamous cell carcinoma?

A 50-year-old patient presents with headache and visual disturbances. MR imaging is performed, and a mass is seen within the clivus. A chordoma is suspected. Which of the following features would be unusual for this diagnosis?
options: Isointense to brain parenchyma on T1W
Lack of tracer uptake on a 99Tc-MDP bone scintigram
Lack of enhancement with i.v. gadolinium
Some regions of low signal on T1W

stem: A patient presents with seizures. An MR of the brain reveals an apparent area of linear meningeal thickening adjacent to an intracranial tumour. Which of the following would make the description of this thickening as a ‘dural tail’ less appropriate?
options: The adjacent tumour is an extra-axial
The area of thickening does not enhance
The thickening is only present on two contiguous 5 mm sections

stem: A patient presents with a cranial nerve palsy, and a CT head reveals a mass in the region of the jugular foramen. Given this location, which of the following structures is least likely to be involved?

A middle-aged man has acute, profound loss of a visual hemifield. MR imaging reveals an acute infarct of the left occipital pole and inferior temporal lobe. To which arterial territory does this correspond?

An immunocompromised patient presents with symptoms of encephalitis. MR imaging is performed and primary CNS lymphoma is considered likely. Which of the following features would be unusual for this diagnosis?
options: A peripheral rim of high signal on T2WI
Decreased uptake of thallium-201 on SPECT imaging

stem: A patient presents with a neurocutaneous disorder. Which of the following is not a recognised association?
options: Von Hippel Lindau disease and pheochromocytomas

stem: A patient presents with a sudden onset headache and a CT head is performed. No intravenous contrast medium was administered. An arbitrary region of interest is drawn, and the attenuation is found to be 25 HU. What tissue type is this likely to represent?

A child undergoes MR imaging of their spine. A review of the lower lumbar levels reveals that the dorsal dura is incomplete and the subarachnoid space lies ventral to a neural placode, which is directly continuous with the skin. The ventral subarachnoid space does not appear to be dilated. What would be the most appropriate term to describe this spinal dysraphism?
A middle-aged man has an acute onset headache and subarachnoid blood is seen on a CT head. An MR angiogram is considered. Regarding cerebral MRA, which of the following is incorrect?
options: MRA should be avoided following the endovascular coiling of aneurysms
Giant aneurysms are better visualised on CT angiography rather than 3D time of flight MRA
Aneurysms smaller than 3 mm are more difficult to detect by MRA imaging
Recent subarachnoid haemorrhage may degrade time of flight MRA imaging
MRA may show aneurysms missed on a digital subtraction angiogram

stem: A child presents with a lump in the neck, and a branchial cleft cyst is suspected. Which of the following features would be unusual for this diagnosis?
options: Attenuation of 10 HU on unenhanced CT
High signal on T2W MR imaging
Located deep to a sternomastoid muscle
Lack of rim enhancement on CT
Present in the posterior triangle of the neck

stem: A 42-year-old woman presents with weakness in her hands. On examination she is noted to have wasting of the small muscles of the hand, burns and cuts to her fingers. There are reduced biceps reflexes, increased tone in the legs, and upgoing plantars. An MRI brain and spine are requested. What is the most likely unifying diagnosis?

You are shown a set of paediatric MR and CT head images during a teaching session. There is a well-defined, lobulated mass within a dilated left lateral ventricle. There is hydrocephalus. It is hyperdense on CT and returns moderately high signal on T2W. There is intense contrast enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
You are reporting plain radiographs. You note a suture line posterior and inferior to the occipitomastoid suture on a lateral skull radiograph of an infant. What is this suture most likely to be?

You are asked to review an MRI brain, and note that there is a focal abnormality of the left globe. There is a localised outpouching near the site of the optic nerve attachment. What is the most likely diagnosis?
